Ken wrote:
<snip>
> And what is the
> capacity of a
> fixed-weight recurrent network to remember
> information?

In this case the ANN is functioning as a general
purpose computer, so it has the equivalent of a
program in ROM, and data in RAM.  The ROM is in the
weights.  The neuron outputs are the RAM.  The RAM has
two functions.  It must provide scratch pad memory to
support the computations, and it must remember and
make available the data required by the problem at
hand.  It's not clear how much is required for the
former.

The total amount of RAM is quite clearly defined:  N
bits in the case of N binary neurons.   So N bits is
clearly an upper limit on the memory capacity of a
fully recurrent binary ANN with N neurons.  Since this
ANN has more than two thousand weights, the memory
capacity seems tiny, in proportion.  Furthermore, some
of it is probably required to support the computation,
and hence not available for the requirements of the
problem domain.

Its relevant to compare this with the theoretical
capacity of the Hopfield network, where the memory of
patterns is stored in the weights.  Each pattern
consists of N bits, and the Hopfield network can store
about N/6 patterns, so the memory capacity in bits is
about N^2/6.  The dependence on N^2 is not surprising
because the number of weights varies as N^2, and the
weights have the memory.

It seems that far more data can be stored in the
weights than in the state vector.  The advantage of
state vector storage would be in speed.  Furthermore,
for certain tasks there may be no way to modify the
weights while solving the problem at hand.  (I might
be wrong about that; I don't really understand how the
weights would be modified during one trial of a card
game.)
